CatDescriptText: Heddie Henderson, housewife, Fifth Ward, and Adolph Bridget, steelworker, Homewood, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, October 28, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., should come to Pittsburgh and take over the pastorate of a church, or should he remain in the South and continue his crusade?"  Mrs. Henderson's answer reads: "He should come to Central Baptist Church because you can't help but like him and the way he speaks.  Also, we need him in Pittsburgh in our drive for equal rights." Mr. Bridget's answer reads: "I rightly think he should stay in the South, because he's needed there.  I don't know of anybody who could step in and do the job that he's doing there."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Heddie Henderson wearing striped dress with three large buttons, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Adolph Bridget wearing zippered jacket and moustache, standing in front of Bud Saunders Flower shop, Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
